ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES



The MPLX Terminals, LLC - Niles LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Niles LP Terminal is an on-shore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Niles, MI. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low sulfur diesel/#2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various petroleum based additives.



Niles LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.



The Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. MPLX promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX has designed and implemented, including:



A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances

B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs

C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals

D. An overview of the emergency response program

E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety



A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The primary function of the Niles LP Terminal, located in Niles, MI is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane tank blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances w

ere identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Niles LP Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Butane Tank Blending Process.



The Butane Tank Blending process is a batch type process based on seasonal RVP adjustments. Butane is received by truck (transports) and piped directly to and injected into the gasoline recirculation lines associated with atmospheric storage tanks. Process safety controls for the offloading skid  that are used include emergency shutoff valves with a fusible element (rated at < 250 deg. F) with local and remote manual actuation; a check valve for instantaneous closure in the event of a pull-away event, and a "Smart Hose" with engineered breakaway capabilities plus self-closing valves at each connection point. Other protective measures/system controls include pipe thermal/hydrostatic reliefs and grounding devices. Access to the Facility is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel, and approved contractors/visitors.



B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES



The Niles LP Terminal accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning/response programs help Marathon effectively manage the hazards posed by the regulated substances to the Terminal employees, surrounding public, and environment. In addition to the training noted above, tours and drills with members of local emergency response organizations are offered routinely. These tours and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with the hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the Terminal.



E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



MPLX is continually striving to make the Niles LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.



In an effort to improve and promote system safety, MPLX actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements. All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT) per MPC policy. The Niles Township Fire Department (primary responder) and the City of Niles Fire Department (mutual aid) are contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additionally, MPLX will work cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.

General Emergency Response



-Emergency alert system;

-Periodic emergency training for employees;

-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies; and

-Emergency drills with Terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.



Further, the Niles LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, a Facility Response Plan (FRP) of "Smart Plan" is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Niles Township Fire Department (primary responder) and the City of Niles Fire Department (mutual aid).



C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Niles LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal keeps records for all incidental and significant chemical releases inclusive of any root cause analyses and associated, follow-up actions. There have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation.



D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Niles Township Fire Department (primary responder), the City of Niles Fire Department (mutual aid), and Berrien County Emergency Management. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) or "Smart Plan" is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.



In the event of an emergency involving the Niles (North) LP Terminal butane tank blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Niles Township Fire Department and request their assistance.
